g.title: n0
g.text: Abortion is morally wrong
It is wrong in principle to kill an
unborn human being

g.title: n1
g.text: It is wrong to kill an innocent person
Note that 'person' is sometimes used
with other meanings in philosophy, but
for the context of this topic means
person in the way that an adult human
is a person while an animal is not.

g.title: n22
g.text: Argument from personhood at conception

g.title: n26
g.text: Substance argument
Also known as the natural capacities
view

g.title: n2
g.text: There are criteria to determine if a
being is a person
The criteria are open to debate, but a
popular set is given

g.title: n23
g.text: Argument from criteria for personhood

g.title: n25
g.text: Infanticide objection

g.title: n3
g.text: An unborn human is an innocent person

g.title: n4
g.text: An unborn human does not meet the
criteria to be a person

g.title: n5
g.text: Humans are essentially people
All biological humans are a kind of
substance which is capable of
personhood as part of their essence.
Note that the terms `substance` and
`essence` have specific philosophical
and metaphysical meaning.

g.title: n6
g.text: Consider a future where it is possible
to move someone's mind out of their
natural body and into a robotic one.
Would killing the natural body still
be the same as killing the person?

g.title: n7
g.text: It is speciesist to use genetics to
decide personhood

g.title: n8
g.text: Determining that humans are essentially
people does not prevent other groups
from being identified as people in the
future

g.title: n9
g.text: In this case it would be wrong to kill
brain dead people or people in a
permanently vegetative state

g.title: n10
g.text: Murder is wrong because it deprives a
person of a valuable future
It is wrong to kill an innocent adult
human because it deprives them of a
valuable future

g.title: n28
g.text: Deprivation argument
Also known as the "future like ours" or
"valuable future" argument

g.title: n11
g.text: The human entity which has a future
like ours is a new entity created at
conception, which is different than
either the sperm or ova

g.title: n30
g.text: Contraception objection
Contraception must then also be wrong,
as sperm and ova then must also a
future like ours

g.title: n12
g.text: A suicidal teenager also has no
interest in their future, but it is
still wrong to kill them

g.title: n31
g.text: Interest objection
A being must be interested in its
future in order for harm to be caused
by taking it away

g.title: n13
g.text: This analogy only holds in the case of
rape

g.title: n32
g.text: Body rights argument
Consider this thought experiment: You
wake up in the morning and find
yourself back to back in bed with an
unconscious violinist. A famous
unconscious violinist. He has been
found to have a fatal kidney ailment,
and the Society of Music Lovers has
canvassed all the available medical
records and found that you alone have
the right blood type to help. They
have therefore kidnapped you, and last
night the violinist's circulatory
system was plugged into yours, so that
your kidneys can be used to extract
poisons from his blood as well as your
own. (If he is unplugged from you now,
he will die; but) in nine months he
will have recovered from his ailment,
and can safely be unplugged from you.
Is it wrong to unplug the violinist?

g.title: n14
g.text: Women who are not provided education on
sex and contraception don't know
enough to have given consent

g.title: n33
g.text: Tacit consent objection
If the woman had voluntary sex then she
gave tacit consent for the child to
use her body

g.title: n15
g.text: Many people are unconvinced that they
would have a different duty to a
familiar than to a stranger and thus
the difference is not morally relevant

g.title: n35
g.text: Stranger vs offspring objection
The violinist is a stranger, a
situation with a familiar would draw a
different conclusion

g.title: n16
g.text: There is no moral difference between an
action with forseen but unintended
consequences and one with intended
consequences (consequentialism)

g.title: n36
g.text: Killing vs letting die or intending
versus foreseeing objection
Abortion intentionally kills an embryo
while unplugging the violinist lets
him die as an unintentional
consequence of your escape (principle
of double effect)

g.title: n17
g.text: Consider the scenario of a family who
was found to be liable for frostbite
finger loss suffered by a dinner guest
whom they refused to allow to stay
overnight, although it was very cold
outside and the guest showed signs of
being sick. It is argued that just as
it would not be permissible to refuse
temporary accommodation for the guest
to protect them from physical harm, it
would not be permissible to refuse
temporary accommodation of a fetus.

g.title: n18
g.text: The magnitude of the accommodation
provided to the dinner guest is vastly
different than that provided to the
fetus

g.title: n19
g.text: There is a difference between natural
and artificial preservation. One is
obligated to provide natural
preservation like gestation, but not
obligated to offer artificial
preservation like persistent blood
transfusion.

g.title: n20
g.text: Arguments against virtue ethics in
general

g.title: n37
g.text: Argument from virtue ethics

g.title: n21
g.text: Factor of moral risk
If a person is considering the morality
of having an abortion, they must be a
moral actor.

g.title: n24
g.text: Comatose adults also do not meet the
criteria for personhood

g.title: n27
g.text: Equality objection
Not all futures have an equal value
(eg. a young adult compared to a sick
elderly person), yet all people must
have an equal right to life.

g.title: n29
g.text: Identity objection
The entity which has a future like ours
is not a biological one, but rather an
embodied mind which is not present
until later in the biological
development

g.title: n34
g.text: Responsibility objection
The woman has a duty to sustain the
child because she is the one who
caused it to be in need of her body
